file_content.text: You truly are relentless. I can see now why Zash chose you. But this has carried on long enough.
Ah, you've come prepared. By now, I should have expected it of you.
Astonishing. I didn't expect one as reckless as you to have prepared such a defense.
Unfortunately for you, I am older and wiser and studied in rituals you can't even imagine.
I have business on Malachor Three. Prepare my ship, and see that this one gets a respectful cremation.
I have business on Malachor Three. Prepare my ship, and dispose of this mess.
Yes, my lord.
My lord, you're awake!
We need to hurry out of here. If Thanaton finds out you're still alive, we're all in trouble.
Which one are you again?
Who are you?
I'm your apprentice, Kaal. We need to get back to the ship.
What happened to me?
My head hurts.
Thanaton tried to kill you. Look, I'll explain when we get back to the ship.
Let Thanaton find me. I'll kill him.
I don't care.
I don't think you have the strength for that yet my lord.
Let's get back to the ship with the others. We can figure out what to do from there.
Hmm. You've put me in a difficult position.
When Zash disobeyed me and had Skotia killed, tradition demanded that she be killed and her power base destroyed.
Believe me when I say I wish that you had stayed in that tomb. It will pain me to watch you die.
Forget tradition. "The Force shall free me." Isn't that the idea?
You don't have to do it.
Without these traditions, the Sith would be so awash in their own blood they couldn't see their enemies taking aim.
I don't understand. I didn't do anything.
But I'm innocent.
Your master openly defied me, and I cannot risk you following in her footsteps.
Spare me the false tears. I'm ready to fight you.
Don't pretend to be hurt.
You are entitled to defend yourself; in fact, I'd expect nothing less.
May the Force welcome you with open arms. Kill her.
May the Force welcome you with open arms. Kill him.
Thank you for meeting me here. Respect for her superiors is the mark of a good Sith.
Thank you for meeting me here. Respect for his superiors is the mark of a good Sith.
Of course, Zash would've disagreed, did disagree with me passionately on that point. But then, Zash never respected tradition.
It's wise to respect your superiors, at least until you're powerful enough to kill them.
Respect until you can strike.
A wise answer. You are not like your master.
Did you call me here just to talk philosophy?
Boring.
Philosophy gives structure to the delicately ordered chaos of our Empire.
Being Sith is about being free, not blindly following an arbitrary set of rules.
Why should she?
Be careful. That attitude may get you in trouble some day.
Tradition. Principles. History. The threads that compose our society. Zash refused to acknowledge how one little tug could ruin the whole tapestry.
Your work was sloppy, brazen even, but the news of her murder was sweet.
I would hate for my actions to disappoint you.
I'm glad it pleased.
I only hope that next time you'll be a little less obvious.
I didn't want to kill her. It was self-defense.
She attacked me first.
Nonsense. Every apprentice wants to kill their master. It's not a fault.
I did my best to clean up the bloodstains.
Murder is messy.
I speak in all seriousness. Too many people saw you enter the Dark Temple. I trust you'll be more careful in the future.
Nevertheless, we're here to talk about you, not Zash. You have demonstrated remarkable ability.
Though I am a stricter master than Zash, I think you'll find that to loyal followers of our traditions, I am not ungenerous.
Then I will do my best not to disappoint you.
I hope I can please you.
In that case, I think we will have a very fruitful relationship.
So, if I agree to your every whim, you might not kill me.
You want minions, not Sith.
Suspicion can be a form of wisdom, as long as it doesn't lead to disrespect.
I know the Sith Code. Is there something else I'm supposed to know?
What do you mean, loyal?
The Sith Code is only the start. You must study the history of the Sith, make it your own.
Now, I wish to see how you work. This tomb belonged to Darth Andru, Sith scholar and alchemist.
I'm interested in his last writings, which were buried with him. Recover them for me, and we will discuss your place in my power structure.
